WonderkidAnswered on 20 Mar 2019The STI comprises the largest 30 companies listed on Singapore exchange, whereas a globally diversified ETF has broad exposure to a wide range of global companies around the world. For example, IWDA ETF has exposures in 23 developed countries, including Singapore with the weight of 0.5%.The biggest difference is the diversification. STI gives you exposures to Singapore listed companies, so if you only own STI the performance will be strongly linked to Singaporeâ€™s economy and stock market performance. A globally diversified ETF will give you a more balanced exposures across countries. To access global ETF you can either use 1) Local brokerage that provide access to foreign exchanges;
2) international brokerage account e.g. Interactive Brokers, TD Ameritrade, Saxo Bank; 3) Robo-advisors such as StashAway.Different accounts have different charges.Size of investments depends on the account, as some account has minimum fixed monthly fee so it doesnâ€™t make sense to invest small amount of money. This is a broader topic on asset allocation which will involves your personal risk appetite and personal finance.0 comments2

Luke HoLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 20 Mar 2019It really depends how long you have to stay invested, so I'm going to give advice off the assumption you have a time horizon of at least 10 years.
1) A globally diversified portfolio means you're investing in economies around the world. So US, India, China, for example. You can start with a lump sum investment, or break it into smaller parts similar to DCA to manage your risk.
Global indices are not too difficult for me to beat, so you could always let me know if Hariz or myself can drop you a message, but otherwise you can always look up the IWDA ETF, for example, which is quite accessible.
2) A sum is only small depending on your needs. If someone is trying to get $10,000 in passive income by 10 years, they need at least $2mil if the passive interest is 6%, of which they should invest quite a bit more than $600/mth. I think you should just invest after ensuring that your cash flow is sustainable. You don't want to compromise your regular investment. Tie it to a goal, so that market drops do not make you deterred easily.I cannot recommend a low-fee broker because I am a high-fee Financial Consultant.
